results.content: Amazing course. Mehul is an excellent tutor. I had watched his youtube videos, which I liked and hence took this course. He explains well. If you are in doubt whether to take this course, just visit his youtube channel codedamn, check out his videos especially his new JavaScript series and be the judge whether you should take this course. You most definitely will want to take this course. This course covers the basic of React Native.

results.content: Very good overview of how to create a React Native application.  Mehul explains things in a very clear manner and breaks things down to easy understand segments.
results.content_html: Very good overview of how to create a React Native application. Mehul explains things in a very clear manner and breaks things down to easy understand segments.

results.content:
First of all, I was developing on Windows and this course is entirely on Mac.
The instructor also uses not a emulator of Android, but a real Android device to run the application. I don't have Android phone so I had to manage how to run the emulator by myself. Also instructor did not even show how EXPO method works and what limitation it has. When programming Settings part there were no loops used, the Settings were hard-coded. The linking to documentation is very poor - each time you have to google to find the displayed page by yourself. And when building an app for Android, it gets really messy because instructor makes some mistakes like copying certificate file to wrong directory then goes back and fix it, etc. He should re-film that episode for sure.

response.content:
Hey Martynas!
Sorry for your trouble. But I do cover setup instructions on Windows too. If you don't have Android phone, I assume you have iOS device, which is also covered. You could continue the series with your iPhone too, doesn't really matter. If anything breaks, you could personally reach out to me.

Thank you pointing out the expo part, I'll add more information on it soon.
For individual video feedback or problems, please comment below those videos as it'll be easier for me to help you there.

Also, if you have any problem anywhere in course, you can reach out to me directly through udemy or through my email address.

First of all, I was developing on Windows and this course is entirely on Mac.
The instructor also uses not a emulator of Android, but a real Android device to run the application. I don't have Android phone so I had to manage how to run the emulator by myself. Also instructor did not even show how EXPO method works and what limitation it has. When programming Settings part there were no loops used, the Settings were hard-coded. The linking to documentation is very poor - each time you have to google to find the displayed page by yourself. results.content:
I'm only up to the getting started part. It's going okay so far. I managed to set up my React Native application on my Android device and even learned how to set up my RN app on an iOS emulator. The instructor is very engaging and easy to follow.

A few improvements could be made. First, I wish every course starts with a course overview (i.e. a short video of what we will be learning for that section) and then go into the topic. It would feel a little bit more organised that way. Second, I feel that pre-requisite installations (IDE of choice, Node, NPM) could be done in a single short video or not at all. I do not know about anyone else but I always thought that people who heard about React Native may have those stuff installed already. Third, I was expecting to learn how a React Native project is set up (i.e. how to set up the folders in a way that is reusable and organised). Haven't learnt it yet this far in the course but once I finish it, I'll update this if it is covered in Section 4.

Also, I looked ahead. I was expecting a Redux introduction. I heard that Redux is important for state management in React Native. Can't see a video heading that has "Redux" written on it. Maybe additional content would be nice to have?

Anyway, besides that, I really appreciate this course. Keep up the great work. I am also subscribed to you on Youtube. Your tutorials helped me throughout my university years. Thank you.

response.content: Hey Chris! Thanks for the review. Nice catch there, I'd probably add (and update) a course overview video. That's a good assumption for the node,npm part, but I wanted to have that just in case people are having permission errors with npm/node while installing react native (or other dependencies), they can fallback to the method I'm using to setup node. I go over setting up a file structure for our basic app, so you'll be knowing that soon. I did not want to bring in Redux for "React Native - First Steps" because trust me, its not really required for small to medium apps having less state management. With context API and new stuff react is bringing, redux is really needed when you have heavy data flow going on, which is something I wouldn't put in "First Steps", haha. Glad you're subscribed, and let me know if I could help in any other way.
response.content_html: Hey Chris! Thanks for the review. Nice catch there, I'd probably add (and update) a course overview video. That's a good assumption for the node,npm part, but I wanted to have that just in case people are having permission errors with npm/node while installing react native (or other dependencies), they can fallback to the method I'm using to setup node. I go over setting up a file structure for our basic app, so you'll be knowing that soon. I did not want to bring in Redux for "React Native - First Steps" because trust me, its not really required for small to medium apps having less state management. With context API and new stuff react is bringing, redux is really needed when you have heavy data flow going on, which is something I wouldn't put in "First Steps", haha. Glad you're subscribed, and let me know if I could help in any other way.

results.content: Overall the course is good for absolute beginner but I think you can enhance this course and make it little more exciting by adding extra things like React navigation, 3rd party UI library or Firebase integration.
